This is a copy of the JSONSchema draft-07, with the addition of the "configScope" property.

It enables this kind of thing while writing a config schema:

{
  "$schema": "https://backstage.io/schema/config-v1",
  # ... config schema
}

Which in turn gives you autocompletion, etc in editors

This is work towards #2854

Open to discussion about the naming of the additional property btw. Originally I used just "scope", but it's a bit too generic and the JSONSchema spec recommends to prefix custom schema additions in order to avoid future keyword conflicts. "configScope" feels specialized enough while not overly verbose, considering alternatives like "backstageConfigScope" or "appConfigScope"

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

We are looking to build a site similar to Backstage with almost identical use cases. (Nice podcast btw @stefanalund!) One of our use cases is rendering dynamic content, stored as markdown, which is updated multiple times per day. Think real-time documentation. It would be unrealistic to trigger a full build process each time there is a content update.

It would be great if Backstage became more opinionated on how the front-end app is served. Specifically, I think it would be great if the front-end app adopted NextJS to serve all web assets. The added capabilities within NextJS would unlock the type of dynamic content use cases I am looking into.

Note: I don't think any of NextJS's API capabilities should be utilized if NextJS is adopted. I think the current app vs backend separation is pretty elegant.

Possible Implementation

I'm not sure what all it would take to implement NextJS within the current code base. My assumption is that there would be a number of manual tasks but nothing architecturally would need to change.

Context

I am still new to Backstage, so maybe there is a way to do this already. Although, any way that is currently supported probably cannot utilize the full power of NextJS given the missing NextJS specific <Link> tags.

Unfortunately, this particular use case (real-time docs) will prevent us from adopting Backstage. So if there is support for an idea like this, we would likely be able to contribute to the implementation. Otherwise, we will have to go our own way. (Which would be a bummer! 😞 )
node.title: Flexible Deployment Model with NextJS

node.bodyHTML:
Status: Open for comments

Need

The new EmptyState and MissingAnnotationEmptyState components are very helpful. However, the current default ones don't necessarily convey intuitive (or complete) instructions for an individual organization. There might be some additional steps before adding any catalog file annotations would be applicable (e.g. CI/CD configuration). It would be nice to be able to customize the content of these components.

NOTE: This is currently possibly by customizing the EntityPage components. However, it requires wrapping tabs and widgets in order to customize the empty state. Having a native/common pattern that plugins use that allow empty state to be customized would be very helpful.

Proposal

My first reaction would be to have both the plugin Router and any Widgets expose a new prop that allows you to override the default empty state component:

<SonarQubeCard emptyState={MyOrgSonarQubeEmptyState} />
// or
<DocsRouter emptyState={MyOrgDocsEmptyState} />

Alternatives

Longer term, I think it would be beneficial to see if the EmptyState / MissingAnnotation components could be extended with additional information. However, I haven't really thought through what that might look like.

Risks

There doesn't see to be a risk in doing this as the default empty state would not need to change and the new emptyState props would be optional. It's purely introducing a pattern to allow customizing and/or overriding the empty state.
node.title: [RFC] Plugins should support custom EmptyState components / instructions

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

Internally at Spotify we have had a very open mindset, where everybody can see pretty much all information available in Backstage, at least for reading - while management/write operations are limited to those that have the appropriate rights.

This is not good enough in some environments. There are many possible reasons for wanting to limit the access to information to certain groups of people, and the catalog is one such place where it would be possible to glean sensitive information by spidering through all of the entities that are stored inside.

There should be a mechanism for users to limit access to their entities.

Scope and Implications

The current assumption is that entities should be treated as completely absent, for users that do not have the correct permission level, such that there's no way to even get a hint of their existence through for example name-guessing. Just the name itself may reveal sensitive information, for example if it hints at a not-yet-disclosed upcoming acquisition or research product of a sensitive nature.

This does have implications on several levels, making the implementation nontrivial.

  • The basic (and possibly easiest to achieve) need is that when listing entities or attempting to fetch a single entity, the user should see a behaviour exactly as if the entity does not exist, if they do not have permissions to see it.
  • When the user tries to register a new entity, that collides with a secret (hidden) entity, the system will have to communicate that in a sane way to the caller, that does not reveal too much information. For example if the message states "you do not have permission to overwrite the API competitor-api" or "you do not have access to accidentally-acquisition-colliding-namespace" or similar, it does leak information.
  • When there are bidirectional references between entities A and B, and the user does not have permissions to see B, then they should not see those relations while fetching A.
  • The above presents a problem if the relation came from the spec - for example, saying implementsApis : [othernamespace/secretthing] since we likely cannot reliably censor the spec data. But this must be regarded as a misconfiguration; this would mean that the user placed sensitive data in a public place, so we probably won't handle that corner case.
  • This may also extend to registered catalog locations, not just entities. The act of registering a sensitive thing from a secret location may be considered sensitive as well.
  • There may be other information sinks that have to be handled one by one. For example, if there is an event bus originating from the catalog that publishes events as entities are registered, changed and deleted, then those events will potentially contain sensitive information as well.

Authorization (out of scope)

This all overlaps with the concept of authorization. If you do not have permissions to view an entity, you likely should not be permitted to delete or modify it either. This is intentionally left out of scope for this discussion, however, the design of these concepts should most likely also take future authorization needs into account so that the concepts can be unified if deemed appropriate.

Possible Implementation

We are still not assigning much logic to the entity metadata.namespace concept. A likely useful abstraction level could be to allow the binding of ACLs, RBAC, or ABAC onto the namespace level. This, coupled with leaving the default namespace open for all per default, would make it a fairly clear user action to make a claim that "users of teams team1 and team2 have read rights on namespace ns3".

Alternative Implementations

  • Security conscious users could install several distinct catalogs, each with separate auth requirements. There could be a low security base catalog A, that contains all of the insensitive data. Then a walled off catalog B could house the sensitive data, plus have a processor in place that also ingests all of the data from A, making B a superset of A without A ever noticing. This would make the implementation trivial (a simple catalog-reader-processor class needs to be written), and gives stronger guarantees and better isolation, at the cost of possibly higher maintenance cost. Also, it works well for the write case, but what if a user that has access to B wants to register a new location - they must then be given the choice of whether they want to do it in catalog A or B. This applies to all write related operations. This places a greater burden on the frontend implementation.

Context

See also discussion in #1401.
node.title: catalog: limit entity read access to certain users/groups

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

There should be a way for catalog API consumers to react to changes in the catalog, without having to resort to polling. There may be reasons to start laying the basic foundations for event driven systems around the catalog.

As entities are added, changed and removed, surrounding systems (or even the service nodes of the catalog itself!) may want to refresh caches or otherwise update themselves based on the new state of things. Add the ability for the catalog to emit events on all mutations.

Possible Implementation

There are many possible event bus / web hook / pub-sub / similar architectures. The initial work here would involve adding the required internal callbacks inside the catalog backend, to allow the registration of any custom publisher mechanism.

Eventually the catalog could come with a few supported publishers, such as google pubsub, aws sqs, rabbitmq, etc.

Context

While this may not be highly prioritised at the time of writing, there have been a few questions about it and we have sometimes felt that it would enable some interesting capabilities internally. One potential usage could be for all of the catalog service nodes to refresh an in-memory RBAC cache each time a relevant change happens according to #3218.
node.title: catalog: publish events about catalog changes

Expected Behavior

E2E tests in CI should not fail for other reasons than bad changes.

Current Behavior

E2E tests are flaky and need to be retriggered often. For example https://github.com/backstage/backstage/runs/1352271046?check_suite_focus=true

Possible Solution

There are a couple of common reasons for failures. I'll list some known ones with possible solutions:

  • yarn install fails because of networking issues
    • Tricky to do much about this one, we could try adding retries but most likely we just have to keep retriggering these.
  • yarn install build step fails (usually nodegit)
    • Try to avoid native modules, especially trying to remove nodegit as a dependency as its been causing some issues in other places too.
  • Failures in using internal packages from other packages in the repo.
    • Afaik this is down to race conditions in executing the pre/post-pack scripts during builds in the CLI. Have not been able to reproduce

Steps to Reproduce

node.bodyHTML:
Status: Open for comments

Need

This might be controversial so I added the RFC tag 😄

The Backstage docs have this "Edit" button, which is (I guess) supposed to make it easy to update the docs using the GitHub UI. I ❤️ this idea and I like to use it. Unfortunately, 2/3 times so far that I have tried to submit changes to docs, prettier fails for me and I have to go and clone the branch locally, run prettier and force push.

Proposal

  1. Prettier should automatically run in a GitHub action against markdown files in the /docs directory.
  2. The --write flag should be enabled enabled.
  3. The result should be automatically committed to fix formatting.

Alternatives

  1. I could try harder to do what prettier demands of me.

Risks

Automated commits always come with some risk. I feel like the risk can be controlled by limiting the filetype and directories that this runs in.
node.title: Prettier should automatically fix and commit markdown files

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

The default backend (in the repo, and as scaffolded by create-app) do not honor the HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY environment variables. This naturally surprises surprised users.

The backend is using cross-fetch, which in turn uses node-fetch, which ultimately uses the built-in http modules - none of which automatically pick up the standard env vars.

Possible Implementation

  1. Introduce a configuration block under backend, both in the in-repo app-config.yaml and the one created by default by create-app:
backend:
  reverseProxy:
    http: { $env: HTTP_PROXY }
    https: { $env: HTTPS_PROXY }
  1. Introduce a dependency on global-agent, both in the in-repo packages/backend and the one created by default by create-app, and initialise it with the above values (only if they are present).

Context

Reverse proxies are common in corporate settings, and this question has been raised several times on support channels.
node.title: Automatically bootstrap https[s] proxy in the backend

Feature Suggestion

Right now the table and filter in the catalog is written manually without the new table filters. The new filter table can reduce the amount of code a lot and provides a consistent user experience between the plugins. We already started to use the component in the API Explorer:

This should bring us the following advantages:

  • No custom code for table filters
  • Generic way to store table state in the URL. This replaces custom solutions like #2730
  • Extend the table with features that we have in the catalog, but are not yet available as a generic component.
  • Consistent style and user experience

Optional, we can also do them later:

  • Make CheckboxTree and Select controlled components
  • Support paging in the table state. The catalog table is using paging and we aren't persisting that yet.

Possible Implementation

Before (or while) we replace the table with the generic one, we have to resolve some things:

  • Build some kind of "category" filter (not sure about the name!):
  • Integrate the new dense styling into the table (Nothing to do here, see #3276).
  • Maybe fix the table header to stay with the old title and row count, right now the new table filter always displays "Filters" and the amount of active filters:
  • Add a way to always open the filter box? We can more or less already do that using the table state.

Afterwards we should be able to delete code in:

  • plugins/catalog/components/
    • components/CatalogFilter/
    • components/CatalogTable/ (some of it, here we integrate the table filters)
    • components/ResultsFilter/
    • filters/

Context

New plugins like the squad plugin #2808 have to copy a lot of code. We should reduce this to the minimum and reuse as much as possible.

I would be up for taking this task in case that is the way we want to go. I'm not sure if this might collide with other things that are done in the catalog plugin, like discussed in #2791.
node.title: Use table filters in the catalog

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

The catalog does not permit any two entities to have the same kind + namespace + name combination - that triplet forms a uniqueness constraint that is properly enforced. But the catalog does not yet handle the case where the same kind + namespace + name entity is read from several registered locations. What currently happens is that one and the same entity ini the database gets overwritten over and over again by the catalog refresh loop as it goes through the competing locations.

What instead should happen, is that the first registered location "wins". Whenever an entity is read from a location and is about to be written into storage, it should be checked that if a corresponding database entry already existed, the write is rejected if the source location of the new entity isn't the same as the old entity.

Possible Implementation

This is a fairly simple change in HigherOrderOperations or possibly in the lower layers that it uses for writes.

Context

This is a feature that we have wanted since the start, and which is already in place in the old legacy internal catalog at Spotify.

Discord discussion: https://discord.com/channels/687207715902193673/687207715902193679/776301455120007199
node.title: catalog: reject attempts to overwrite entities through competing locations
